awd_titl_txt: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Linguistic and Political borders in the Senegambia region
awd_abstract_narration:
A border drawn around the Gambia River by French and British colonial powers was officially recognized in the 1889 by the Berlin Conference, as part of the process known as the "Scramble for Africa." This colonial boundary has left an enduring political rift between the nations of Senegal and The Gambia in spite of their shared history, ethnicities, and indigenous languages. One of the major ethnolinguistic groups divided by this border is the Wolof. Although Wolof continues to be an important shared language between these countries, speakers recognize divergence in the Wolof of Senegal and The Gambia. Language is often used to construct and reinforce ethnic, social, and national identity and can evoke a strong sense of solidarity or separation among speakers. As Peter Auer has argued, not only can the national border help construct a linguistic border, but the linguistic divergence can also serve to reinforce the national border. This dissertation will focus on the border in a multiethnic, multilingual area where ethnicity is strongly associated with language.

Under the direction of Dr. Brian Joseph, Jane Mitsch will spend eight months in the Senegambia border areas conducting sociolinguistic interviews and ethnographic fieldwork among Wolof people. This dissertation aims to examine the linguistic practices of people with shared ethnic identity but different national identity, to explore the role of the political border in the linguistic practices of these young nations, to elicit data on different identity affinities (national, ethnic, religious etc.), and to compare the linguistic results to other linguistic studies of political borders. This study will bring linguistic input to political science questions about the strength of African nations and their borders. This research will also lead to the creation of a corpus of spoken Wolof that will capture some of the important aspects of the Wolof oral tradition such as folktales and proverbs.

por.por_cntn:
Political borders serve as powerful instruments of inclusion and exclusion, and language use often reflects membership in these geographic communities. Sociolinguistic studies have shown the potency of political borders in shaping the linguistic landscape. For instance, Canadian border communities’ resistance to a sound change that is sweeping northern United States cities (Boberg 2000), or the historical divergence of a common Germanic dialect after the establishment of the German-Dutch border (Auer 2005). These studies illustrate how political borders can be reinforced by linguistic borders and can play a role in language change. They have also focused on predominantly monolingual areas in Europe and North America. My dissertation is an ethnographic and sociolinguistic study of borderland life and language use: how is the West African language Wolof spoken in the borderland between Senegal and The Gambia. Although colonial and postcolonial politics have divided a speech community, Wolof is the lingua franca, but exists alongside several other local languages as well as the exogenous official languages (French in Senegal, English in The Gambia). Prior to becoming a borderland, this area was part of an indigenous kingdom known as Saloum. Using sociolinguistic and ethnographic evidence, I examine how the border influences social and linguistic practices of Wolof speakers in this borderland where history, culture, religion (Islam), ethnic (Wolof) and local identity (Saloum) are shared, but nationality is divided.

 

Living in this border area and engaging in participant observation for nine months in 2013, 160 sociolinguistic interviews were collected in four different communities on both sides of the border, including both urban and rural sites. Using linguistic variables at the phonetic, morphosyntactic, and discourse levels, we assess to what degree the political border also constitutes a linguistic border. Through the lens of their social and linguistic practices, this research focus on how the border is constructed and/or subverted and the meaning(s) discursively ascribed to it by local inhabitants. As a relatively young border, this site adds a non-Western dimension to the literature on borderland language variation that has focused on European and North American studies (Boberg 2000, Auer 2005, Llamas 2007).

 

My findings suggest that the border is not a monolithic entity, but like Auer (2005), I suggest that its cognitive salience can create dialectal divergence. Its cognitive reality, however, is mediated by the relationship between speakers' identities and the nation-state. Urban-dwelling individuals and young men seem to use the features associated with Senegalese or Gambian Wolofs and see the border as the limits of particular national characteristics. Many borderland inhabitants operate in unofficial religious or commercial networks and prefer linguistic features associated with a more localized, transborder Saloum identity. The political border for these individuals is more or less something to be exploited or even circumvented for economic advantages or in accessing spiritual leadership and community. These findings show that the porosity of West African borders may yield different linguistic results in the process of linguistic border construction.
